Name: Walt Disney's Peter Pan Game
Description: Spin and move children's game based on Walt Disney's Peter Pan
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Peter Pan

Name: Clock-A-Game
Description:
Trivia game with a wind up clock that displays the questions and answers from a "player piano" type roll.

Features 3 categories.  US Presidents, Countries of the World and Domesticated Animals.

Name: Nightmare Hunter
Description: Players fight strange monsters in two worlds--the real world and the dream world--with different strengths in each place. This game has several two-sided location cards, where one side shows the real world version and the other side shows the dream world version.  These locations are the battlegrounds, against monsters like the Wandering Stuffed Toy. Special cards use dream imagery, like Psycho Slip (doorways hovering in space), Escape (from monster), and Corridor of a Dream (running on a moebius strip).

Name: Jr. League Magnetic Baseball
Description: Dexterity Baseball game featuring a magnetic baseball and played on a metal board.  The game features a lever activated pitcher and batter.

Name: Director's Choice
Description:
From the game box:
"Watch the full Length movie (optional), re-direct 16 scenes from the movie and answer 900 movie trivia questions."

This version uses the movie: A Star Is Born
Staring: Frederic March, Janet Gaynor and Adolphe Menjou

Basically this is a roll and move game with the object of moving your "actor" from the "dressing room" to the "stage" by answering trivia question specific to the movie "A Star is Born" and also generic Hollywood trivia

Box Components include:
Gameboard
Tokens and dice
Trivia Cards
VHS cassette tape w/ full length movie

Name: Koop- en Kaapvaartspel
Description: Players need to collect dukaten (money) by selling coffee, tea, tobacco and other goods by buying or hijacking each other ships.

Name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
Description:
Expansion for 2006 release The Pillars of the Earth. 
Included in this expansion are The Pillars of the Earth Expansion Cards. (Mayfair Games and Filosofia edition only!)

With this expansion, new elements of the novel come into the play. The players can put mercenaries for the crusades at the disposal of the king, send their building masters to Toledo, or take over the office of the tax collector. And with the enclosed material, the game can be played with a fifth or sixth player.
Families: Series: The Pillars of the Earth (Kosmos)

Name: Space Rockets Card Game
Description:
"From the Makers of UNO!" #-1079 As it so boldly claims on the package, while this was also 'Made in Belgium'! There are 34 cards in denominations from 1 to 10, as well with 2 instructions kinds for the couple of variations with this. One of those is a seemingly "WAR!" sort of game for just 2 players, and the other means would be through a "Rummy" type that allows from 2 to 4 of whom can play, using the same deck. There are some decently rendered 'Spaceships' drawings for EACH of the 10 cards and the entire contents are contained within a DECK "pack" for it all.

Recommended Ages 4 - 7, while parents may wish to have this in order to teach younger players some of the varying methods that "cards" can be used in playing GAMES with such.

Name: Big Fish Lil' Fish Shark Shooter
Description:
From box back.

Avoid the Shark!
Play your Cards!
Watch Out!

Play your cards as quick as you can, but don't get caught in the cross-hairs of the Shark Shooter!  In this twist on the classic fast paced, feeding frenzy card game Big Fish Lil' Fish, you'll try to eat lil' fish with big fish while avoiding the card-shooting shark.  If someone points the shark at you, move fast, or you could get stuck with all the fish it shoots out!

Includes:
2 Decks of Big Fish Lil' Fish cards
1 Shark Attack Card-Shooter (Requires 3 C sized batteries)

Name: LOBO
Description:
This game is a rummy style collecting game based upon the underground [subway] railway [railroad] stations of London, England. From names of stations and fact that Thomas De La Rue, address as given on my pack is given as 110 Bunhill Row, London EC1, which was destroyed by bombs during WW2,this game dates from 1930s.  The pack consists of 72 cards - 50 unique station cards which have small photograph of area around station, 16 junction cards i.e. EARL'S COURT, BANK & MONUMENT, HOLBORN [x2], KING'S CROSS, OXFORD CIRCUS, TOTTENHAM COURT ROAD, LEICESTER SQUARE [x2], PICADILLY [x2], BAKER STREET and CHARING CROSS [x4]. and 6 exactly the same Season Tickets [which act as jokers for interchange cards.]
The Object of the game is go LOBO by making up a hand of two or more completed journeys either exposed or unexposed.  A completed journey consists of a junction card together with two station cards.  On the junction card are printed the names of starting or finishing stations made through that particular junction.
Although rules state that game can be played by any number there is a limit to number of players which is constrained by the size of the pack which I suggest is 6 at most.

Name: The Titans of Terror vs. The Forces of Good
Description:
If you would dare to experience a maelstrom of miniature mayhem, then enter the world of "The Titans of Terror vs. The Forces of Good", Ral Partha's first installment in a throat-clutching trilogy of horror. This foray into the fantastic has been created exclusively for Sculptor's Row by one of the world's top fantasy sculptors, Dennis Mize.

An avid collector of classic monster movies, Dennis Mize has designed the "Titans" to capture the look and feel of the classic Fantasy and Sci-Fi films of the 50's and 60's. The "Titans" are presented in a "serial" format, so that each new boxed set will contain the latest "episode". These scenarios, when combined, will reveal the complete and mesmerizing tale of "The Titans of Terror".

Name: Ultimate MindTrap
Description:
The Ultimate MindTrap - the Challenge Continues is an incomparable collection of 300 all new murder mysteries, brainteasers, trick questions & visual experiences that will capture your imagination & challenge the way you think... and see !

In the twisted world of MindTrap, your team will encounter a variety of challenging categories. You will confront the classic mystery scenario that is richly illustrated & riddled with both clues & red herrings. Then you'll find yourself racing the opposing team in shaping a Tangram teaser or assembling a beguiling matchstick puzzler. Or for a completely different twist, stretch your imagination to identify a magnified photograph of a common object that you know you know, and yet, it hovers there, defiantly out of reach. All the MindTrap questions are written in humorous prose with a delightful twist that will make you laugh at the surprisingly simple solutions.

In MindTrap, it's not what you know that counts... it's how you think !

Name: BattleTech: Total Warfare
Description:
It is the 31st century, a time of endless wars that rage across human-occupied space. As star empires clash, these epic wars are won and lost by BattleMechs, 30-foot-tall humanoid metal titans bristling with lasers, autocannons and dozens of other lethal weapons; enough firepower to level entire city blocks. Your elite force of MechWarriors drives these juggernauts into battle, proudly holding your faction’s flag high, intent on expanding the power and glory of your realm. At their beck and call are the support units of armored vehicles, power armored infantry, aerospace fighters and more, wielded by a MechWarrior's skillful command to aid him in ultimate victory. Will they become legends, or forgotten casualties? Only your skill and luck will determine their fate!

The product of more than twenty years of gaming experience, Total Warfare presents the rules of the Classic BattleTech game system as never before. For the first time, all the rules for various units that have a direct impact on the deadly battlefields of the thirty-first century appear in a unified rules set: from BattleMechs to ProtoMechs, Combat Vehicles to Support Vehicles, infantry to aerospace fighters and DropShips. Interwoven and meticulously updated, Total Warfare provides the most detailed and comprehensive rules set published to date for BattleTech—the perfect companion for standard tournament play.

Total Warfare is the single-source rulebook for people who play Classic BattleTech. It is not intended to teach new players the game, but rather to serve as a reference work for people who know the game, while introducing more technologies and expansive rules than appear in the basic box set. The introductory game in the BattleTech line is the Classic BattleTech Introductory Box Set. New players should pick up that product before diving into this one. Construction rules for the various units presented in Total Warfare can be found in Classic BattleTech TechManual.

Corrected Second Printing by Catalyst Game Labs.

Expands:

     BattleTech
     BattleTech: Introductory Box Set

Name: Classic BattleTech: Starterbook – Sword and Dragon
Description:
A new series, the Starterbooks are a perfect way to jump into the further excitement of the Classic BattleTech universe once players have tried their hands at BattleTech. Starterbook: Sword and Dragon provides a short synopsis of the conflicts between the ancient enemies of House Davion and House Kurita, as well as a brief history and personal dossiers on the members of these two legendary combat commands. Including record sheets for everyone in the command - which includes eight, never-before-seen ’Mech variants - as well as a unique track system that allows players to develop their own scenarios, players will be firing autocannons and tossing PPC lightning at one another in no time!

The Classic BattleTech Introductory Box Set is required to use Starterbook: Sword and Dragon.

Expands:

     BattleTech
     BattleTech: Introductory Box Set

Name: Who's the Richest?
Description:
Aim: To be the richest to travel around the world. When one of the players run out of money, the game is over. The winner will be the one with the most money and property.

Players choose a coloured plane to represent themselves, and start out with a specific sum of money. They take turns to spin the arrow dice for the number of squares that their planes may fly on the board. Players have the option to build their house on the country squares they land on, but they can do this for free if they spin the arrow dice and it lands on "Free" (located on a different circle from the one used for movement). If players land on a space which already has property built, rent is to be paid to the house owner.

The game is similar in some ways to Monopoly, but with more options. In addition, it plays more quickly than Monopoly due to the endgame condition which requires only one player to run out of money before the winner is determined.

Name: Party Time
Description:
In Party Time the players play in two teams. One player draws a card and has to explain/describe, draw, pantomime or knead up to three words/items. Depending on how many items his/her team guesses the team's pawn may advance 0, 1, 3 or 6 steps along the board. On the cards you have clusters of three terms per action to be taken. The action a player has to take (explain, draw, pantomime or knead) is decided on the field the pawn is situated on.
You also have a flash symbol on the board. Whenever a pawn starts its move on the flash symbol, this goup must take an special card and one player has to do whatever is written on the card (e.g. "non-sense" like explain terms using a certain slang, stand and one leg and put off your shoes and socks, keep your breath for 90 seconds...).

Game No. 71245.0 from F.X. Schmid, published 1994 (1993 ParaDice)

Name: Tactics
Description:
From the box cover: "The new, realistic land army war game! Designed and perfected by an infantry officer... A war game with the professional touch... Actual principles of war apply... A real mental exercise... An excellent gift for the 'Chess and Checkers' type"

Tactics is a landmark game in that it was the first cardboard-counter commercial board wargame that was intended (albeit with limited success) to accurately simulate warfare and command.

The game was self-published by Maryland National Guard infantryman Charles S. Roberts, who would go on to found of Avalon Hill Games. The original edition of Tactics was published by the Avalon Game company, with a print run of approximately 2000. Roberts sold Tactics by mail order out of a garage in Avalon, Maryland.

The game portrayed a modern day strategic conflict between the forces of two hypothetical countries. The opposing units included infantry, armor, and airborne forces. The game was played on a mapboard which used a square grid rather than the hex-based style map which would later became preferred in the board wargaming industry. However, many of the conventions and mechanics established in Tactics still live on, in one form or another, in many of the wargames published today.

Based on his success with Tactics, Roberts decided to expand his operation and in 1958 he formed Avalon Hill Games. The initial line-up of games from Avalon Hill included Tactics II, a revised version of Roberts' original wargame. Avalon Hill would go on to publish a 25th Anniversary edition of Tactics in 1983, which represented a modified version of the original game in that it used a prototype mapboard which had not previously been released.

Other than a few graphical changes there are some functional changes from the Tactics map to the Tactics II map:

Going over the 1954 Tactics and 1958 Tactics II boards square by square the only functional changes are:
 - The squares around the edge of the map for 1958 now have numbers 1 to 43 from North to South and 1 to 55 West to East.
 - Cities for 1958 had unique numbers added. 
No numbers are present on the 1954 board in the cities or the grid.
 - There is no map compass on the mapboard label like there is in Tactics II
 - The mountain pass in the large mountain range on the board label edge is not present on the 1954 map. Also there is only one single clear square, same place as in Tactics II, 7 squares in from the Blue coastal city near the map label in that mountain range. There are none of those longer dead end corridors in the big mountain range like on the Tactics II map.

Re-implemented by:

    Tactics II
    Tactics (25th Anniversary Edition) (25th Anniversary Edition)
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Bolos and Krags: The Philippine American War 1899-1902
Description:
(from the designer:)

On June 12, 1898. Filipino revolutionary forces under Emilio Aguinaldo declared proclaimed independence of the Philippine islands from the colonial rule of Spain. The declaration of independence however was not recognized by the United States of America and Spain since the Spanish government ceded the Philipines to the USA in the aftermath of the 1898 Treaty of Paris which formally ended the Spanish American war (April 25 to August 12, 1898). Tensions already existed between both sides due to conflicting movements of independence and colonization further aggravated by misunderstandings on both sides and feelings of betrayal on the Filipino side. The tensions escalated between the former allies on February 4, 1899 when a Filipino soldier was shot by an American soldier (William W. Grayson) in Manila. Fighting soon erupted in Manila and culminated in an official Filipino declaration of war by the Malolos congress on June 2, 1899. The war would last 3 bloody years and would see a short conventional war followed by a long guerilla war which would be a prelude of things to come in Vietnam 60 years later.

---

"Bolos & Krags" is a simulation of the Philippine American War 1899-1902 which saw 4 years of brutal guerilla war resulting in 4,000 American soldiers and a million and a half Filipino dead. The war influenced Mao Tse Tung to refine his people's war guerilla doctrine which would haunt the U.S. in Vietnam and Iraq many decades later.

Area impulse action movement system.  280 counters, 12 pages of rules, area map covers all of Luzon. units are leaders of regiment sized battlegroups which you equip with companies in a system similiar to Death In the Trenches/CSA. Victory centers on Political will (like Byzantium Reborn/Battle For China). Combat is the NO CRT wescom system from Death in the Trenches/CSA. Has Strategic chits(from Storm Over Taierzhuang) to give both sides a wealth of strategic options. Lots of random events.

The game shows the political and military dimensions of the war. 16 bimonthly turns. In a historical, easy to play and learn, balanced and interactive format. Playable within one evening. Interesting situation as the U.S. with military supremacy tries to fight a guerilla war with determined but poorly equipped Philippine Republic insurgencts in one of the most roughest terrain in the world.

This game includes:
Mark Twain, Bandit hunts, guerilla warfare, atrocities, Sun Yat Sen, Boxer Rebellion, Philippine Constabulary, President Mckinley, 1900 U.S. presidential elections, epidemics, Mao Tse Tung (Ok, a cameo in the random events), General Joe Wheeler, typhoon, hearts and minds and more...

This game is probably the first wargame on the Philippine American war 1899-1902 and this game will shed much needed light on a obscure part of American history.

Name: Ruthless
Description:
The Ruthless board played with two decks of cards and 16 marbles in four different colors.

Designed for Seattle-area senior citizens, the Ludo-like game is played with cards.

Name: Pocket Ungame: Families
Description:
This is the Family version of Ungame. This set has new cards that are specifically designed for siblings and parents to get to know each other better and explore each other's feelings.

There are 140 cards divided into two decks of 70 cards each. The first deck contains lighter questions such as, "If our family inherited a million dollars, I would like for us to _______." Most of the questions in the first deck are about families in general and not about individual members of the family. The second deck is composed of more specific questions, such as describing your feelings about other family members or explaining how you felt when a family-member hurt your feelings. Other cards allow the player to talk about any subject they choose.

Players take turns drawing cards and answering the questions on them in a few sentences. Most of the rules are considered as guidelines, such as the "hint" to keep your answers fairly short, but the Rule of Silence during another player's answer must be observed.

As with other games in the Ungame series, there is no winner or loser. The object of the game is to spend quality time with your family and learn more about the thought and feelings of those closest to you.
Families: Admin: Outside the Scope of BGG

Name: 2gether
Description:
A party game where you must use your whole body to be ably to win. You play in teams and work together to succeed the different tasks your team gets. Example on tasks can be; get your team to act like famous statues, move a ball around team without using your hands, show one feeling with your mouth and the opposite feeling with your body etc.

You can read more about the game at www.2gether.se

Name: Princess Quest
Description: The princess will wed the brave adventurer who is first to win three specific treasures (randomly selected among twelve treasures). This card and dice game is unusual for also having a map of the kingdom and cardboard chits for adventurers and monsters.  It is something like Ravensburger's "Enchanted Forest" crossed with a Japanese card and dice game--players must travel the kingdom and memorize the location of the different treasures, all the while fighting monsters and messing with the other players.

Name: Ex*Pion
Description:
In this abstract strategy game you win by either bringing a special neutral unit called the Ex*Pion in your base by pushing it step by step with your own units, or by capturing all of your opponents' unit. You capture your opponents' units by enclosing them with your own units. The Ex*Pion being a neutral unit, it can be used to capture units, but cannot be captured.

Winner of the 1990 As d'Or on the game festival of Cannes.

Name: Dios Patria y Rey The Carlists Wars, 1833-1840
Description:
Alea Magazine #32.

Dios Patria Rey (For God, Country and King) is a system simulating several battles of the First Carlist War of 1833-1840.

The Carlist Wars in Spain were the last major European civil wars in which pretenders fought to establish their claim to a throne. Several times during the period from 1833 to 1876 the Carlists — followers of Infante Carlos (later Carlos V) and his descendants — rallied to the cry of "God, Country, and King" and fought for the cause of Spanish tradition (Legitimism and Catholicism) against the liberalism, and later the republicanism, of the Spanish governments of the day.

Dios Patria Rey uses a beefed up and revised Libertadores system (Soldados y Estrategia n. 10) to simulate eight of the most decisive battles of this war: Arquijas, Luchana, Oriamendi, Barbastro, Maella and the 1st and 2nd battles of Perecamps.

The game features the several foreign units which fought in Spain in 1833-40 including the British, Portuguese and Belgian legions and the French Foreign Legion. There were also French, Prussian Austrian and Russian Absolutist fighting on the Carlist side. In fact, the Carlist pretendant died in exile in the Austrian Empire. He is buried in a church at Trieste, now in Northern Italy.

Name: Strontium Dog: Hell Planet
Description: Game originally published in the Starlord comic book, based on the Strontium Dog comic. Play bounty hunter Johnny Alpha, Bestiariz, Cy-Ko, or Sergeant Syn. The first one to capture five targets wins the game.

Name: T-Rex Rules
Description:
From the back of the box:

From Anklyosaurus to Velociraptor, these giants that roamed the earth are colorfully depicted on these cards.  With over one hundred dinosaur facts (2 each per card), kids will really become dinosaur experts.  Players match up pairs of cards, whoever is left holding the Tyrannosaurus Rex card becomes king of the dinosaurs.  T-Rex rules!

Name: The Murder-Mystery Party Kit
Description:
David "Ditch" Digger, the owner of the Summerlot Resort in the Catskills has been killed. Whodunit? Was it his gold-digging wife? The hunky lifeguard? The wacky driver?

Everything needed to throw a murder-mystery party is inside this very small 3"x3" box: six name tag stickers, six 12-page booklets (1 for each character), and a 32-page host guide.

Name: Dalmania
Description: Dalmania is a game for Dalmatian lovers.  This is a simple spin-and-move game.  The players move on the board and have various paths to pick from on the way to the goal.

Name: Main Line
Description:
It states on the small maroon rexine covered box - Waddy Production Main Line a THRILLING GAME THAT IS "different".

Players - any number from 2 upwards.  It should not exceed five if only one pack is used.  Use two packs when players number 6 to 10.

Cards - one pack consists of 50 cards showing various configurations of track with card values.

Start - players are dealt cards, the number depending on how many players, and the remaining cards are left in a face down stack.

Object of game - to get rid of all ones cards by laying cards so as to continue either the red main line or yellow branch line. Players either play one card or take a card from the remaining stack. The general idea is like a game of dominoes. At the end of a game players count up the points on cards still in hand.

The Winner is the player with least [or no] points counting against him.

Name: La Course aux Fruits
Description:
Ah Fruits!

Albert the farmer is a very old man who can't really go around is farmland to pick is fruits like he used to.
So instead of letting is fruits rot on the ground, he gathered a few of his animal friends to help him out with his tedious job.

But if you give a basket to a duck, a dog, a pig, a turtle and a hedgehog, confusion is bound to happen!

With all of their good will and dedication, our little friends can't stop bickering and start little competitions between themselves to see who will gather the most fruits!

Name: Tosenkyo
Description:
What is the Tosenkyo?


To-sen-kyo means throwing-fan-amusement. To contest your skill with your rival, aim the target, toss the fan, and then refer scoring chart for victory points (VP). Although its elegant image made some fantasy like "game of Heian Era from a millennium ago", it is only legend. According to evidences of manuscripts, it might be flourished from middle of Edo era (about 1770s).

Skilled veteran makes victory points constantly. Beginner may hit big score luckily. Because of this easily enjoyability for everyone, it won popularity once among commoners.


    Difference of Tosenkyo from Darts


As same throwing game, Tosenkyo is frequently compared with Darts. The most significant deference of Tosenkyo from Darts is way of scoring. VP of Darts are gained from stabbed area directly. But in Tosenkyo, after hitting fan dropped the target down from the Base box, VP would be determined between distance and over/under positions of fan and target (and sometimes Base of target). Beginner cannot win almost against veteran in Darts. But in Tosenkyo, scoring system has some happening factors. Some beginner may hit big lucky score and win against constant veteran. This makes the game unexpectedly thrilling and exciting.

In fact, adequate proportion of luck factor against cool rule is the joyous essence of Tosenkyo.

Page: http://www.tosenkyo.net/whats-e.htm

Name: Carcassonne: Expansion 5 – Abbey & Mayor
Description:
The fifth major expansion to Carcassonne, Abbey & Mayor adds 3 new wooden piece types, 6 abbey tiles, and 12 landscape tiles. The Abbey tiles act as Cloisters but do not have to match adjacent tiles and they complete adjacent features when placed. Mayors can be placed only in cities, with their strength determined by the number of pennants in the city. Barns allow players to score fields during the game rather than just at the end. Wagons are placed on roads, cities, or cloisters, and can move to an adjacent open feature when their current feature is completed.

Part of the Carcassonne series.

Expands:

    Carcassonne

Name: Spreadbet
Description: Spreadbet is a trivia/economic/wagering boardgame that uses the mechanics of the growing phenomenon of 'spread betting'.   Each round, one player takes his or her turn to set their estimate of the answer to a trivia question like 'the height of the Eiffel Tower', and pays out or collects from the other players after they have gone 'higher' or 'lower'.

Name: DAF Transport Game
Description:
In this game players act as delivery drivers for DAF trucks, driving them through Europe to where they're required.  Sometimes, in addition to delivering the truck, there may be a cargo to deliver on the way.  Each time a successful delivery is made, the player gets a Delivery Bill.  The winner of the game is the first to get a complete set of Delivery Bills.

This is principally a roll and move game, but players can use the die roll to move 1, 2 or 3 trucks, as long as the total moves equals the number on the die.

Contents:
game board
die
24 card holders
18 truck cards
6 road blocks
36 route cards
36 cargo cards
6 service tickets
18 devlivery bills
rule book

Name: Channel
Description: Each player has 10 numbered disks and 10 numbered slots (Channels) on his base that each disk goes into.  The board is  a grid pattern.  In the middle of the board is the scoring base.  The scoring base as 10 numbered slots like each players base.  The scoring base also has four channels to move disks through.  Each turn a player may move one of his disks one place; forward, backward, left or right.  Each player is trying to get his numbered disk in the same numbered scoring slot on the scoring base.  Each scoring slot only holds one disk.  Players may use their disks to block slots and channels.  When all scoring slots are filled players add up the total of a each players respective scoring slots with the highest winning.

Name: Muffin
Description:
Muffin the Mule was a children's television program made by the BBC through the late '40s and the '50s. This game displays characters and events from the television show.

The game is basically "Strip Jack Naked" or "Beggar My Neighbour" with players playing the top card from their deck to a pile in the centre of the table. If a numbered card is played then the next player must pay cards in succession equal to the number on the card. If while paying out that player turns over a numbered card then the next player must now pay for that card. If a player pays cards to match the required number without revealing a numbered card themselves the player who player the numbered card collects the entire stack from the centre of the table and adds it to the bottom of their own pile.

This game has the addition of 2 Peregrine the Penguin cards. When one of these is revealed the first player to shout "Muffin" instantly wins the centre pile.

Play continues until one player has all of the cards.

Name: Krimi Total Fall 6: Der verfluchte Schatz der Piraten
Description:
The 6th in the KRIMI Total series. This time the setting is Broken Island in the Caribbean and players are trying to find the long lost treasure of Broken Island. But as the keeper of the treasure has been found dead, a curse now lays over the island. What happened?

Released: Essen 2007. Ages 16 and up.

Name: War: Stalingrad
Description:
The Wargame system is devoted to battles of WWII (1939-1945).

It models tactical level of combat operations. A corresponding card represents each military formation. They may be infantry, armor, artillery and aircraft units, or even special troops (e.g. Guerrillas). As a rule a card depicts certain military unit, usually company or platoon. Game parameters of unit cards are adjusted to reflect not only their power but also tactical capabilities in terms of the game mechanics. Resource cards reflect the economic powers of each side, which enable them to build and maintain armies and to take military actions.

Name: Diabelski Krąg
Description:
Diabelski KrÄ…g is a tactical game in which (in it's basic version) two players compete to either defend or kill a infantile princess of a fantasy kingdom untill the dawn for 3 nights (time is randomly simulated after each turn). The "good side" are four powerful mages, while the "evil side" are eight demons.

Though tactical, the game is pretty random, since the demons change their statistics every turn due to the changing phases of the moon and stars. Demons can change their status, there are 8 stages of it, from 100% material (they can be hurt and they can fight) to 100% spiritual (they can fight only using psychic attack, but can pass through the walls, etc.). Demons can use fireplaces to move, cast a curse, use pentagrams and holes to hell. Mages can use garlick, Torch of Ithilien's Temple, Ilih's Weed, wand, salt, Magic Book, Elvish Drop, pray and exorcise.

One of the last games by Sfera.

Name: 1, 2 oder 3
Description:
In this free game that is part of the German magazine Spielbox (number 3/2007), all players rush from start to finish. But at the end of the game it's not the fastest the winner but the player with most coins.
Each player starts with 12 coins. Every player has always three cards with values of 1/2/3 to move his pawn accordingly.
The first player chooses a card, all other player try to guess what value he has chosen. This first player will move his pawn according to the value of the card but the other players have to compare their guesses.
Were they right, then they have to move one field further than that first player. The first player has also to give them a coin. 
A player that guessed wrong only moves one field ahead ignoring the card he has played.
The First player changes every move around the players. The game ends with the first player reaching the finish field.

Name: BattleTech: TechManual
Description:
How does a MechWarrior interface with a BattleMech? How does a ProtoMech really work? When was the Gauss rifle or the Particle Projector Cannon developed? Or how can I just make my own, cool and unique BattleMech design? If you've ever been plagued by these questions, then get on your coveralls and make sure you’ve got your astech certification, because you’re about to dive into BattleTech construction!

A companion volume to Total Warfare, the BattleTech TechManual combines all the construction rules for the various units presented in that core rules set. Streamlined and updated, it contains all the core weaponry and equipment from previous rules set, as well as the newest, bleeding edge technologies. More than just a rulebook, however, the TechManual presents numerous source book-style treatises, providing the in-universe context for these units and the technologies of their development. A must have resource for any BattleTech aficionado!

Expands:

     BattleTech: Total Warfare

Name: Classic BattleTech: Map Set – Compilation 1
Description:
Classic BattleTech® Map Set Compilation 1 contains 24 previously published maps for use with: Classic BattleTech and BattleForce®

Includes:
From Map Set 2:

* Mountain Lake
    * River Valley
    * Lake Area
    * BattleTech
    * CityTech
    * City Ruins
    * Desert Hills
    * Scattered Woods

From Map Set 3:

* Desert Mountain #1
    * Desert Mountain #2
    * Desert Sinkhole #1
    * Desert Sinkhole #2
    * Rolling Hills #1
    * Rolling Hills #2
    * City Hills/Residential #1
    * City Hills/Residential #2

From Map Set 4:

* Heavy Forest #1
    * Heavy Forest #2
    * City Street Grid/Park #1
    * City Street Grid/Park #2
    * Large Lakes #1
    * Large Lakes #2
    * River Delta/Drainage Basin #1
    * River Delta/Drainage Basin #2

The maps in this compilation have their terrain clearly marked on every hex. Each map is printed in full color.

Expands:

    BattleTech: Introductory Box Set
    BattleTech: Battleforce

Name: Classic BattleTech: Map Set – Compilation 2
Description:
Classic BattleTech® Map Set Compilation 2 contains 22 previously published maps for use with:
CLASSIC BATTLETECH, BATTLEFORCE® and AEROTECH 2®

Includes:
From Map Set 5:

* Large Mountain #1
    * Large Mountain #2
    * Deep Canyon #1
    * Deep Canyon #2
    * Open Terrain #1
    * Open Terrain #2
    * Moonscape #1
    * Moonscape #2

From Map Set 6:

* City (Downtown)
    * City (Residential)
    * City (Skyscraper)
    * City (Suburbs)
    * Wide River
    * Woodland
    * Box Canyon
    * BattleForce 2

From BattleForce 2:

* Planetary Assault Map (1 & 2)

From BattleSpace:

* BattleSpace (4)

The maps in this compilation have their terrain clearly marked on every hex. Each map is printed in full color.

Expands:

    BattleTech: Introductory Box Set
    BattleTech: Battleforce
    AeroTech 2

Name: L'Invincible Armada
Description:
Small wargame which depicts the naval battles in the English Channel between the Spanish and the English fleets in the 1588 Spanish attempt to invade England.

It includes:
- 16 big counters to cut and mount
- a 30 x 20 cm map
- a three-pages rules (in French)

Name: Primal Men
Description:
Players take control of a primal human race and try to be the first to evolve from Australopithecus to Homo Sapiens.

The map is divided to different tiles and each one has a number on it. Active player throws the dice and populations in that tile multiplies and possibly gains a power card. The idea is to multiply & try to spread ones race to the far corners of the Earth. By discarding power cards (instead of playing the effect written into them) players can develop their muscles so that they can drive their rivals away from the fertile forests or generous jungles. Or alternatively they can develop their food diet and outbreed their rivals and beat them by sheer numbers. At least that way they can better afford the occasional bestial attack or an epidemic disease. However, player's can't hold on to their good locations forever because every time they want to evolve to the next level only a small fraction of their population can make the leap while the rest continue to populate the area.

Name: Jeepers Leapers
Description:
Jeepers Leapers is a children's game suitable for Ages 3 - 6.  
"Catch the most frogs before they leap off their lily pads!"

Foam frogs are placed randomly in the holes on a rotating board (the lily pads).  A pair of dice with coloured sides are rolled and all the players dive to grab frogs that match the colours on the dice.  For example, if the colours red and blue are rolled, then either blue frogs on red lily pads or red frogs on blue lily pads can be collected.  Players are awarded point tokens for the frogs they hold, and the frogs are returned to the pond.  The board is then rotated so each frog is now on a different coloured lily pad.

Name: Projex
Description:
Projex (Projective Hex) is a Hex-like abstract strategy game: two players take turns to occupy hexagonal cells, competing to build a chain of occupied cells across the board.

For Projex, the hex grid wraps around at the edges to form a projective plane.  Six pentagons (or three squares) must be included among the hexagons for the whole plane to be tiled.

A winning chain is any loop which encircles the projective plane, in the sense that it is not topologically equivalent to a trivial loop.  As with Hex and Y, the game has the mathematically appealing property that when the board is full, exactly one player will have a winning chain.

				
				
					References
     Designer's post to sci.math describing the game
     Description at gamerz.net

Name: The Emperor's Arena
Description:
The Emperor’s Arena is where legends are born.  Lured by the promise of all the treasure one can carry from the Emperor’s Vault, heroes thrust themselves into combat with the Emperor’s fiercest monsters, the most diabolical of tricks, and the most blood-thirsty competitors.  To those who can survive an hour in the arena, a life of fame and fortune awaits.

In The Emperor’s Arena, you and your opponents take control of rival teams of heroes battling for fame and fortune within the Emperor’s Arena.  As time progresses, the Emperor will release increasingly dangerous opponents into the ring, requiring you to decide how much punishment your active hero can take before tagging to the next team member.  Fame is gained from slaying monsters and attacking other players.  The player whose team has gained the most fame by the end of the game wins.

Name: Super 5 Salto
Description:
Follow up to 5 Alive with new special cards and a different way to get lives.

Players take turns playing cards and adding up the total - you want to take the total over 21 so you gain a life. First Player with 5 lives wins!

Name: Trail Drive
Description:
Trail Drive by the Aarco Playing Card Company of Chicago, New York, Los Angeles and Toronto. From the box; Round up your herd and hit the trail with your Chuckwagon, Cowboys and Longhorns in this exciting new game of the West. Watch out for rustlers, pardner, good luck on your TRAIL DRIVE.

The game includes 40 new Western Cards and a rule card.  For boys and girls Ages 6 - 12

Rules: 
How to Play Trail Drive

THE GAME: Try to play as many cards as you can each turn to build a long Trail Drive with a Chuckwagon, Cowboys and Cows, laying your cards in a row on the table in front of you. A Rustler might stop you, but a Sheriff gets you started again.
THE DEAL: If four or more play, deal 4 cards apiece, then play that round, deal 4 more and play again, continuing to deal and play until the deck is used up. If three play, deal 5 cards apiece each round. If two play, deal 6.
THE PLAY: After each round is dealt, beginning at left of the dealer you each play what you can from your hand. The first three cards must be 1 Chuckwagon and 2 Cowboys in any order; then you add cows, the more the better. Discard the rest of your hand, face down. After each round the discards are added to the bottom of the deck. You may play a Rustler card to stop anyone’s Trail Drive when it has cows. Then no more Cows may be added, until a Sheriff is played on the Rustler. You may start a new Trail Drive, when your first Drive is rustled (with 1 Chuckwagon, 2 Cowboys, then Cows, as before), but you may not play on more than one Trail Drive in one turn. Therefore, you may not play a Sheriff card and start a new Drive in the same turn.
When Deck is used up, whether or not it comes out even, the dealer calls, “Last Round.” On the last round, each player passes to the next player the cards he can’t use, instead of discarding.
THE WINNER: When all possible plays have been made, you each take out all the Rustlers, plus two Cows for each Rustler. Count the rest. Whoever has the most wins.

Name: What If?
Description: What If? is a fun question and answer game designed by Diane Rogers and dated 1968.  What If is the hypothetical question game for teens and adults. Game comes with a couple of pamphlets with questions to be asked and a set of rules on how to play the game rules. The game box is 8-1/4 x 10-1/4 x 1-1/2.

Name: Flesh
Description: Game originally published in the British comic book 2000 AD, issues #8-11. Based on the comic Flesh were rangers from the future travel in time to kill dinosaurs for meat.

Name: Magic 8 Ball: The Board Game
Description:
From the back of the box:

It's the classic Magic 8 Ball with a twist!
The Magic 8 Ball now includes a ticking timer for a ridiculously unpredictable party game. Consult the Magic 8 Ball and race to the finish line by competing in over 70 wild, physical and mental challenges.
Complete the challenge and hand the Magic 8 Ball to the next player. Now it's their turn to do the same. Lose a challenge? Forfeit a token.
Mind-numbing hilarity that will have you rolling on the floor, literally.
But hold on to your tokens. The "Great Eight Potentate" in round two dictates the price players must pay to win back lost tokens.

Name: Thud Ridge
Description:
Air Combat Wargames Rules & Scenarios for Vietnam War-era battles.  For use with 1/600 scale aircraft.  http://www.tumblingdiceuk.com/aircraft.html

Website: http://www.wingsatwar.com

Name: Bible Match Ups
Description:
Includes a 2-sided gameboard to play two separate games:

" Match*A*Book " 
" The object of the game is to match books of the Bible in pairs. 
Any two books in order are considered a pair. 
For example: if Luke is captured, it would take either Mark or John to make a pair. "

" Match*A*Verse " 
" The object of the game is to match halves of Bible verses. "

Name: Dinosaur Dash
Description: This is a children's game themed on dinosaurs.  Players roll their dice and compete to move their set of 4 dinosaurs to safety.

Name: Spooky Math Games
Description:
Packaged in the form of a thin, staple bound book with 5 dice, Spooky Math Games is a collection of 13 games, each with a strong mathematical slant, and each with a kid-friendly 'spooky' theme.  Many of the games require additional components, be it a deck of cards, counters, a hand drawn board, or a combination of all the above.

A common mechanic used in many of the games has players roll a number of dice and then perform addition, subtraction, multiplication and division on the results in order to reach a target number.

The included dice are black with white pips, with a square of bones runs along the perimeter of the faces.  4 of the dice have a standard configuration, while the fifth depicts a cartoon skull in place of the '6', and has additional meaning in some of the games.

The games presented in the book are:


    Spider Legs
    Pirate's Watch
    Picking Through The Pumpkin Patch
    Ghoul's Place
    Haunted House
    Ghost's Grave
    Sitting on the Picket Fence
    Broomsticks Up!
    The Devil's Arithmetic
    Skeletons in Your Closet
    Witches' Brew
    Lucky 13
    Stomping Through The Graveyard


Sequel:

    Spooky Scary Math Games

Name: NASCAR: Chase for the Nextel Cup 2007
Description:
From the press release:

The new for 2007 game features drivers who qualified for The 2007 Chase for the NASCAR Nextel Cup, which is NASCAR’s version of playoffs. The 12 drivers who are highlighted in the game along with their race cars are: Jimmie Johnson, Jeff Gordon, Tony Stewart, Carl Edwards, Kurt Busch, Denny Hamlin, Martin Truex Jr., Matt Kenseth, Kyle Busch, Jeff Burton, Kevin Harvick and Clint Bowyer. The drivers were determined Sept. 8 after the Chevy Rock and Roll 400 race at Richmond International Speedway.

Players race around the racetrack game board, trying to be the first to cross the finish line for the 10 races that make up The Chase. They collect chips for the races they win, and the player with the most race chips at the end of the game is the winner.

Along the way, players try to avoid the Crash Zone and Pit Road but zoom forward when they land on a Drafting Advantage space or play a Pass Card. The game board also has several Chase Challenge spaces, which might help lucky players take the lead or avoid a crash. Players who aren’t so lucky might be warned about changing track conditions or a tire that’s losing air.

Name: Dino Dominoes
Description:
No reading is required and dinosaurs rule in this dino-domino matching game for kids ages three to eight. It includes twenty-eight extra thick colorful dominoes and represents yet another fun way to improve matching skills.  Children can learn color-matching, social interaction, recognition and concentration skills.  These Dino Dominoes also help kids pronounce the dinosaur names.

Ages 3 - 8

Name: Igels 2: Waschtag
Description:
Igels 2: Waschtag is an expansion to Igels: Das Kartenspiel and adds two new groups of animals: raccoons and birds. The fight for food is even more difficult now with 5 or 6 payers. But new munition is added as well.

Ages 10 and up. Released: Essen 2007

Expands:

    Igels: Das Kartenspiel

Name: So spielt die Welt
Description:
Scheduled for Essen 2007

"Bambus Spiele No 2" 
This book offers a glimpse into the boardgame scene of Northern Ireland, Finland, Poland, Israel, Madagascar, Japan, Thailand, Singapore, Australia, USA (extra chapter about Hawaii) and Brazil. 
It also offers rules of local games and games from Michael Schacht, Günter Cornett, Rudi Hoffman, Joli Quentin Kansil and others.

Name: Themaword
Description:
Themaword is a word game: random letters are placed on the gaming table, the players draw a category card and must find a word in the corresponding category, containing only letters found on the gaming table.

Categories include: domestic animals, verbs, colors, food, vegetables, ...

Name: NI-SHI-KI -shouden-
Description:
NI-SHI-KI -Shouden- is a pocket sized version of NI-SHI-KI: The Sliding Samurai Card Chess meant for head to head combat.

NI-SHI-KI -Shouden- contains 13 Warlord cards, which are all new and different from the large version (examples; the powerful Tokugawa Ieyasu and Shimazu Yoshihiro).

Name: Ro-jaws' Robo-Race Game
Description: Originally published in the British 2000 AD comic. Play Ro-jaws, Mek-quake, Hammer-stein or Dr. Feeley-Good in a simple roll-and-move game. The first player to reach Greasy Gracie's Robo-Bar is the winner.

Name: Face to Face with Dice
Description:
Subtitled: 5000 years of dice and dicing
This 192-page book covers the entire history of dice in many cultures.  It summarizes the many dice that have been found in sites of antiquity around the world.  The history then moves into various efforts to outlaw or tax gambling with dice.  There's also a chapter on dice cheating and another on modern dice.  The book is peppered with interesting stories and legends that revolve around dice.  If you ever wondered why many bone dice are hollow, it's explained.  If you want to know where the best museum exhibits of dice are, it's also covered.  The origins and evolution of many dice games are covered as well.

The book is heavily illustrated with drawings and photographs.

The copy I read was a complimentary copy published under the auspices of Dice & Games Ltd and translated from the original Dutch.

Name: Dragon War: Pandora's Box
Description:
This set contains 1 board game card with 12 Pandora's Box cards.  If a player dares to peek inside Pandora's box, evil sprites can be unleashed upon the board.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Zombie Graveyard
Description:
This expansion adds a new card for the board and 5 zombie counters to make it even more challenging for the players to survive and take the Dragon Throne.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Underwater Way Set
Description:
This set includes 10 underwater cards that get inserted into the game.  To pass through the underwater section one will need to get to air squares, or they will end up being easy prey for the massive underwater creatures in the underwater section.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Gypsy Caravan
Description:
The Gypsy Caravan adds 1 oversize board with 4 cards for the board and 6 wares reference lists.  This expansion allows players to pick up new weapons and powers that will help them make there way to the Dragon Throne.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Long Life Set
Description:
This set offers 5 life extender cards and 5 life counters.  The cards allow players to play with more life and go all the way up to 75 points for marathon games where many expansions are being used at once.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: The Shadowland Set
Description:
The Shadowland Set adds a giant side board for the Reaper.  No good comes to a player that is forced to play through the Shadowlands.  It also comes with 4 new fate cards and a card for the board.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Power Cards Set
Description:
This 10 board game card set adds cards that are inserted into the board and can only be accessed by certain players.  When they are accessed they grant bonuses to the character that accessed it.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Character Enhancement Fate Card Set
Description: This 34 Fate Card expansion will enhance one's Dragon War fate deck with all new Fate Cards and a new class of Character Enhancement Fate Cards.  These cards will give one's heroes great new powers as they vie for the Dragon Throne.

Name: Dragon War: Movement Fate Card Set
Description:
This expansion adds 34 Fate Cards with art by Robert Kraus and Eric Kempher.  The fate cards play a huge role in surprising your opponent in Dragon War and this set adds more to the original fate cards, as well as introducing a new type of movement Fate Card that can be used at any time.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Rak Character Pak Set
Description:
This expansion adds 5 new character cards, 5 character tiles and 5 life counters to allow for more players.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Kinetic Kardz Set
Description:
This 9 card set adds game board cards that are randomly inserted into the board and flip and spin or catch players that encounter them.  The Demon and Labyrinth cards are especially nasty.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon War: Jurassic Valley Set
Description:
This expansion adds 9 cards that form a valley of lost dinosaurs that players will have to pass through on their way to claiming the Dragon Throne.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Dragon Wars: Pregame Character Enhancement Charts
Description:
This set expands the original Dragon War game and allows players to add special abilities to their characters for use in the game.  Each character has different special abilities they can gain, and they vary from game to game.

Expansion to Dragon War

Name: Barricade Disney
Description:
This is a children's version of Malefiz aka Barricade. You only have 2 pawns instead of five. There are only 4 barricades instead of 11. And the board has fewer fields.  If your pawn is taken by another and this happens on the top  half of the board, you don't have to start all over again. In that case you may start again in the middle of the board. There are also secure places on the board. If you are on a blue field with a drawing of Pluto, you're safe from attacks of other players. Barricades can not be placed on the blue fields. There are even simpler rules (with one pawn) for children between four and six.

Though it is somewhat confusing, Ravensburger produced a Spongbob version of both Junior Malefiz and Barricade, the latter is a version of Malefiz.  These two different items used the same cover artwork but differed on the board layout, rules, and numbers of figures.

Name: 360° Air Hockey
Description:
360° Air Hockey with sound FX.
Fast flipper action for 2-4 Players. Ages 5 and up
It' just like air hockey.The object is to try and score in your opponents goal. The first one to score 10 goals first wins!

4 Player:
Place puck in center and let the fun begin! First person to 10 wins! Every time you shoot the puck into your own goal you lose a point. Just keep score on the score marker by sliding it over the number of pucks you have shot into an opponent's goal.

2 Player:
Same as above only the inserts are used to block two of the goals.

Other ways to play:
Place all 5 pucks on the playing field at once. When you have let 10 pucks into your goal you are out! Place one insert in to block one goal and continue this way until only one person is left....and you have a winner!

Takes 2 D batteries

Name: Livequiz
Description:
Livequiz is a trivia game where questions are updated on a daily basis, on the internet: one can connect to the website of the game and find new questions.

The game is composed of a gaming board and 400 hundreds questions cards. As most questions concern the news, the answer can change from day to day and are therefore not printed on the game material itself, but can be obtained the Internet.

Name: Munchkin Cthulhu 3: The Unspeakable Vault
Description:
Publisher's DescriptionKick open the Unspeakable Vault!

For years, Goomi has been unleashing his own vision of Cthulhu upon the world, in his comic "The Unspeakable Vault (of Doom)! Now his unique take on the Elder Gods comes to Munchkin, in the form of Munchkin Cthulhu 3 - The Unspeakable Vault.

This 56-card expansion brings Great Cthulhoo, Dagoon, Narly, and Tindaloo into the pun-filled world of Munchkin. Feed your friends to Cthulhoo, grow Footicles, and use your Inhuman Moan to defeatthe Teeny Weeny Mi-Goo.

What darkness lurks in the Vault?


     More Madness! Fear books (logical enough, given the number of tomes that can eat your face), ichor, even phobias themselves!
     More Monsters! Face Goomi's versions of the Mythos gods and creatures... Ygo, 'Zathoth, Nightgaunts, Ghouls, Deepoines, and many more!
     More Things That Put The Hurt On Monsters! Wield the Roman Candle, the giant Hypodermic Needle, and the... Can Opener? Sure, why not? After all, this is Munchkin!


The Unspeakable Vault - more "yum yum" for your Munchkin Cthulhu game.

				
				
					OtherPart of the Munchkin series

This game is also included in the Pegasus Spiele Edition of Munchkin Cthulhu 2 (in German).

Name: Eierlauf
Description: This is a twist on the usual game in which participants compete in a race while they balance an egg on a spoon.  In this one, 10 different items are given to 2 teams of children.  You can try to stack as much items on your balancing sticks as you want whenever it is your turn to race, but you risk slower speed, and if any of the items fall, it is back to the starting point.  But if you succeed in bringing a stack of items from the start to finish, then you can leave the items at the end point and go back to the starting point to pick up some more or pass to the next player in your team.  The team that completes all the items first wins.

Name: AT-43 Army Book: Red Blok
Description: A 64 page supplement for the pre-painted miniatures game AT-43 Initiation Set: Operation Damocles with background and rules for using the collectivist and revolutionary Red Blok army in the game.  Adds complete details for the first new army not found in the original game.  Printed in full color.

Name: AT-43 Army Book: Therians
Description: A 64 page supplement for the pre-painted miniatures game AT-43 with background and rules for using the relentless and enigmatic Therian army in the game.  Adds to the choices found in the Advanced Rules Book, including new units and factions.  Printed in full color.

Name: On Q
Description:
Scheduled for Essen 2007

A small 2-player abstract. The gameboard is a Q and on each space there are 2 stones. Stones have one of 4 colours and are neutral. Players take turns to remove stones from the board and place them in one line in front of them. Getting can only be done from either and of the Q, Placing can also be done to either and of the cue in front of the players.
The objective is to avoid stones with a colour not anotherwise in the cue.

Name: Zamboni Wars
Description:
A little roll-and-move shoot-'em-up game using a Treehouse set of icehouse pieces, Martian Coasters, and a 6-sided die.

Players use stacked nests of pyramids to represent a Zamboni with a giant laser on top - the mechanics are simple, run around the board, shoot at your opponent until you're the last one on the field.

Since the pieces are nested, each time your Zamboni is hit, another bit comes off, leaving a more vulnerable core piece to be shot at the next time. After three hits, you're out!

rules are here - http://icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Zamboni_Wars

Name: Jännittävät jäljet!
Description:
"Exciting Tracks!"

Each player represents one of six large mammals found in the Finnish nature (wolf, lynx, elk, bear, wolverine and rabbit). From the starting area, paths of circles lead to a picture of each animal. The game is divided in two phases; in phase I, players try to collect the footprints of their chosen animal, being occasionally hindered by Wind or Snow. Phase II starts as soon as one player has collected all 14 footprints of their animal, and in this phase the players use their collected footprints as "stepping stones" to reach the picture of their animal on the board; naturally, in this phase those who managed to collect more prints in phase I have a better chance of success. Winner is the first player to reach their goal.

This is a reworking of a similarly themed game by Peliko's preceding publisher Paletti, WWF Taktinen Luontopeli, using very similar components and game board.

5 Finnish marks (about 1.30€ in 2020) from the sale of each copy were donated to Lastenklinikoiden Kummit RY, a Finnish charity raising funds in support of five university hospitals providing a clinic for children.

Published with the new Peliko logo already, while the Finnish mark is still in use; therefore, this is from sometime in the 1990's.

Name: Aeronautica Imperialis: Tactica Aeronautica
Description: The first expansion for the of the Aeronautica Imperialis, an aircraft miniatures game set in the Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition) universe. It is a 128 page hardcover book that expands the game and features new aircraft, scenarios and rules. It also includes hobby material, a variant campaign system  and a new campaign narrative on the Typha-IV conflict, depicting a desperate air war fought between the Imperium and the Tau Empire.

Name: Excel Saga Boardgame!
Description: Excel Saga Boardgame! is a simple roll-and-move game included with the US DVD release of the anime series Excel Saga (Volume 5).  Players choose between six characters represented by included circular punch-out tokens.  Players then roll dice to advance along the board's path in typical roll-and-move fashion.  There are numerous spaces with special instructions, such as playing rock-paper-scissors to advance, rolling a certain number, or singing the series' theme song.

Name: How to Host a Kids Party: Safari Adventure Party
Description:
A children's party game (presumably a birthday party) with a unifying theme (safari) and a loose deduction element, a la adult How to Host a Murder parties.  In this game, the children are attempting to rescue an animal by playing games and listening to a cassette tape.

Contents:
- cassette tape
- shopping/gathering list
- 16 activity (game) cards
- 12 safari postcard invitations
- animal footprint clues
- safari poster sticker game (stick-the-panda = pin-the-tail-on-the-donkey)
- 12 jumping frogs
- 48 safari cards
- small jungle animal
- party favors: 12 each of compasses, magnifying glasses, puzzles

This is one of three HtHaKP themed games.

Name: Sally the Sunflower
Description:
An unusual game where players take turns trying to place magnetic bees onto magnetic spots on the face of Sally the sunflower. If the polarity is correct the bee sticks, if not Sally turns her head away.

From the manufacturer:
"Will Sally turn her face away or let your bumblebees land? Sally the Sunflower shows children the wonder of magnets all through the fun of play! Watch their enjoyment as they try to make a positive connection by landing their bumblebees onto Sally's face! The first to get all their bumblebees onto Sally's face wins!"

Name: Hordes: Evolution
Description:
Evolution is the first expansion to the Hordes miniatures game, which in turn is a completely compatible sister game to Warmachine.  The book adds new units for each of the four Hordes factions, and new neutral Minions.  Also included are painting guides, campaign rules and compiled errata and clarifications for the main rulebook.

The book itself is 192 pages in full color available in both soft cover and hardcover versions.

Expands

    Hordes

Name: His Coming
Description:
From the box:
"His Coming - More than just a game!"

This is simply a roll-and-move and question answering game with a heavy Christian theme.
Game comes complete with board, instructions, pawns, cards and a bible.

Ages 8 and up

Name: Couple Up!
Description:
From the box:
"A hooker of a party game... fun and laughs for the entire family! Similar to the party game Twister but you couple yourself up with hooks! Ages 8 to adult."

Players use elastic bands around arms and legs to pass hooks from one player to another.

Name: Find the Chicks
Description: Players move their mother hens around the barnyard, trying to gather their chicks. Mothers are connected to chicks by magnetic attraction (in the base of their pieces).

Name: Hometown Trivia
Description: In this trivia game featuring Oshkosh, WI, you move around a board featuring businesses from the city and answer questions relating to it.  You need to visit the businesses (which are all real Oshkosh establishments) to collected Product & Service cards in order to win. It was developed in the 1980's by David A. Colbert.

Name: Räkna rätt
Description:
Mfg suggested Ages 7 - 9
The game consists of 36 domino tiles.
One half of the tile contains a digit between 1 and 9 and the other part a picture of a number of fruits, animals or objects that are well known to every child.
The tiles are shuffled and dealt. The aim is to play the tiles one by one and then trying to match the digit and the number of objects of the already played tiles on the table.
The tiles are color coded to make it easier for the youngest children.

Name: Master Farmer
Description: This is a nice little self-published game by John Deere. Essentially a spin-and-move race game with a farming theme.

Name: Taitavat lentäjät
Description: The name of the game translates into English as Skillful Flyers and it's about birds. Actually there are three different games in the box that are all playable with the same set of components. The games are of different difficulty levels and it's intended that as the child grows the game(s) can grow together with him. The goal of all the three games is to collect a specified set of 15 different animals.
